pageContext.claim: “And if the drugs don't stop [coming through the border], we're going to put tariffs on. It also costs our country at least $500 billion through our southern border -- $500 billion.”
pageContext.analysis: This is a flawed estimate. The White House Council of Economic Advisers estimated in a 2017 report that “the economic cost of the opioid crisis was $504.0 billion, or 2.8 percent of GDP” in 2015. But that's not all due to drugs coming across the border. It also “includes individuals who abuse prescription painkillers such as OxyContin and Vicodin and individuals who abuse heroin or other illicit opioids,” the report said. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has said that prescription drugs were involved in more than 35 percent of all opioid overdose deaths in 2017, as FactCheck.org noted.
